column4: I have created a 250MB swap partition when I install Ubuntu, but df shows that the swap partition mounted is only 5MB in size. Why is this?
df shouldn't show a swap partition at all...
You sure you're not confusing swap with tmpfs? What does "free -m" say?
266MB
What, free -m says you have 266M swap? Then you do. :-)
but why is it that the mount point of my swap partition is "none", and df shows that none is 5MB?
df doesn;t show swap. Swap isn't mounted, as such. df *does* show tmpfs, however, which you might be using. That'll just grow or shrink depending on what's used.
But tmpfs isn't swap, in case that's not clear. tmpfs is a scratch filesystem held in memory, used for things like lock files, POSIX shared memory, and other things you needn't care about much.
This is quite strange. I got tmpfs, but also something called none in df.
Yep, that's normal. WHere's it mounted? (The last column)
/dev. But /dev in turn is mounted on /.dev according to df.
Oh, and do "df -Th", which'll print the filesystem type.
/dev is where the "special device files" live. Basically they're pretend files that just exist to make things like disks, memory, etc all look like files.
If you have something mounted there, it's probably devfs or some other magic filesystem. Technically a "virtual filesystem", meaning it doesn't exist on a disk anywhere.

Ahh.. it is a tmpfs :) thanks a lot. It's just that totem doesn't want to run totally because I'm supposedly out of ram, and what I saw in df kind of make me suspect that the harddrive is partitioned incorrectly, which I simply let Ubuntu to take care of my harddrive.
Okay. free -m tells you about ram. You need to look at the second number in the second line, generally.
The second number in the third line is how many M of swap you're using - that should be low.
Thanks a lot dwd, you are great.
I know. ;-)
:) Just one more thing, what is this -/+ buffers/cache thing right underneath Mem?
What's the error in Totem, exactly?

I ran it and it closes immediately. So I ran it under console to catch the error message and it says something like "insufficient resources" or something like that. Naturally I assume that it is because I'm running low on memory.
insufficient resources is a little vague... What's the actual text it prints? (Run it in a terminal window, highlight the text it prints, and middle-click on the IRC client.)
I can't reproduce it again now. But I remember it said something about "BadAloc"
